original_table_html:
Company Product-Oriented Definition Market-Oriented Definition
Chipotle We sell burritos and other Mexican food. We give customers “Food With Integrity,” served with a commitment toward the long-term welfare of customers and the environment.
Facebook We are an online social network. We connect people around the world and help them share important moments in their lives.
Home Depot We sell tools and home repair and improvement items. We empower consumers to achieve the homes of their dreams.
NASA We explore outer space. We reach for new heights and reveal the unknown so that what we do and learn will benefit all humankind.
Revlon We make cosmetics. We sell lifestyle and self-expression; success and status; memories, hopes, and dreams.
Ritz-Carlton Hotels & Resorts We rent rooms. We create “The Ritz-Carlton experience”—a memorable stay that far exceeds guests’ already-high expectations.
Starbucks We sell coffee and snacks. We sell “The Starbucks Experience,” one that enriches people’s lives one moment, one human being, one extraordinary cup of coffee at a time.
Walmart We run discount stores. We deliver low prices every day and give ordinary folks the chance to buy the same things as rich people. “Save Money. Live Better.”
summary_markdown: This table contrasts product-oriented definitions with market-oriented definitions for several companies, illustrating a shift from focusing on what a company *sells* to the broader *value* it provides to customers and society. Product-oriented definitions are direct and functional, such as Chipotle selling "burritos and other Mexican food" or Facebook being an "online social network." In contrast, market-oriented definitions emphasize customer benefits, aspirations, and experiences. For instance, Chipotle offers "Food With Integrity," Facebook "connect[s] people around the world," and Home Depot empowers consumers to "achieve the homes of their dreams." This structure highlights how companies can redefine their purpose from tangible goods or services to intangible benefits like lifestyle, self-expression, experiences, or even societal impact, as seen with NASA's mission to "benefit all humankind."
